title: As Floods Approach, Divers Plug Up Sewers and a Pump Failure Wakes the Mayor
summary: Resume Subscription. GRAFTON, Ill.-With the Mississippi River swelling toward one of its highest levels ever, Mayor Rick Eberlin considered a stretch of buckling roadway and worried about all the ways the river could sneak past a temporary flood wall to rush into his city of 652 people.

title: State Dept. Forces Out Official Who Worked on Plan That Led to Ex-Employer's Arms Deals
summary: Ex-Raytheon outside lobbyist took part in department's decision to fast-track sales, according to current and former U.S. officials. The State Department has forced out a senior official who played a role in crafting a plan that led to billions of dollars going to the defense firm he formerly represented as a lobbyist, according to current and former U.S. officials.

title: Boaz Weinstein Sues BlackRock Alleging Governance Failings
summary: BlackRock says Saba knew or should have known about the funds' bylaws when it invested. Saba Capital Management LP, a $1.7 billion hedge fund run by Boaz Weinstein, has sued BlackRock Inc., arguing that the world's largest asset manager has moved to block outsiders from gaining board seats at three of its funds and effecting change.

title: The ADP Report Gets No Respect at All, I Tell Ya
summary: The ADP report is the Rodney Dangerfield of economic statistics. It isn't true that everyone hates the ADP National Employment Report. Everyone doesn't know about the ADP report.

title: Democrats and the Border Children
summary: Why won't good liberals help even with the humanitarian mess?. At least two migrant children died in May at the U.S.-Mexico border, including a boy with the flu and a 10-month-old who drowned in the Rio Grande. President Trump is misguided in using tariffs against Mexico to solve the border mess, but he's right about the crisis of families with children arriving to exploit U.S. asylum law. He's also right that Democrats refuse to help.

title: Indicting the Parkland Coward
summary: Was Scot Peterson's inaction against a shooter criminal?. Is cowardice a crime? The state of Florida says yes. On Tuesday it arrested Scot Peterson on 11 charges related to his shameful inaction at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School during one of the bloodiest school shootings in American history.

title: Coffee Doesn't Kill After All
summary: California has a moment of sanity, and a lawyer is furious.. California's regulatory regime is enough to give anyone the jitters, so good news that the state signed off Monday on a new rule admitting that coffee won't kill you.

title: Stitch Fix Shares Surge as Client Count Fuels Revenue Growth
summary: Company reports 17% gain in number of active clients for its fiscal third quarter. Stitch Fix Inc. shares rose nearly 30% in after-hours trading Wednesday as a boost in its customer count and spending helped lift revenue and profits beyond Wall Street forecasts.

title: Fitch Downgrades Mexico's Sovereign Rating
summary: Credit-ratings firm cites Pemex, the economy and trade threats from U.S.. MEXICO CITY-Fitch Ratings lowered Mexico's sovereign debt rating, saying the deteriorating credit profile at state oil company Petróleos Mexicanos weighs on government finances while the economy is underperforming and the country faces external threats on the trade front.

title: Ice-Cream-Truck Owners Accused of Avoiding $4.5 Million in Traffic Tickets
summary: New York Ice Cream founder, others also accused of creating new shell companies to avoid paying violations. New York City sheriffs on Wednesday seized a fleet of ice cream trucks, accusing their owners of racking up $4.5 million in unpaid traffic tickets over a 10-year period and creating new shell companies to avoid paying the violations.

title: YouTube Bans Hateful Videos From Platform
summary: Company also will remove content denying events like shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School. YouTube said it is stepping up efforts to scrub hateful content from its platform, including videos that deny historical events like the Holocaust, taking on more of the task of judging the validity of information on its popular video-streaming site.

title: Fiat Chrysler's U.S. Sales Chief Files Whistleblower Lawsuit
summary: Executive in charge of Ram pickup brand says auto maker slashed his pay by 90% after he cooperated with investigators, according to court filing. A top executive at Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV filed a whistleblower lawsuit against the Italian-American auto maker, claiming the company cut his pay in retaliation for cooperating with a federal investigation in the U.S. into its sales-reporting practices.

title: Security-Device Maker OSI Says U.S. Ends Bribery Probes
summary: Investigations were revealed after a short seller alleged bribery in Albania. U.S. authorities have closed foreign-bribery probes into OSI Systems Inc. following the dismissal last month of a shareholder lawsuit against the maker of airport security systems, the company said Wednesday.

title: Bill Ending Religious Exemptions on Vaccines Stalls in Albany
summary: Medical and public-health organizations widely support the legislation. As the rate of new measles cases in New York City has slowed, so too has the momentum behind a legislative bill in Albany that would repeal the religious exemption to New York's school vaccination requirements.

title: China's 'National Security' Hypocrisy
summary: It bans Wikipedia and cavils about U.S. treatment of Huawei.. Visitors to China often find a notice in their hotel rooms advising that popular websites such as Google, YouTube, Facebook , Twitter and even Wikipedia aren't accessible in the country. Beijing bans those sites in the name of "national security." The Chinese view is that the Great Firewall and the resulting effect on foreign companies are necessary to prevent the free flow of information from challenging Communist Party rule.

title: Can the West Still Govern?
summary: Trumpian nationalism may be on the rise, but most democracies are in gridlock.. Donald Trump, the best golfer ever to set up shop in the Oval Office, announced in London this week that because of departing Prime Minister Theresa May's efforts, the Brexit deal is "teed up." Teed up? With this remark, Mr. Trump gives new meaning to "mulligan," golf's infamous do-over for a failed shot. Britain's politicians are at least 40 shots over par on Brexit, having shanked, hooked or topped every ball they've tried to hit.

title: 'The Longest Day' Review: On the Beaches of Normandy
summary: With his seamless ﬁrst-person accounts, Cornelius Ryan captures the ﬁnest hour of a common people's refusal to give in to tyranny of the basest sort.. Sixty years ago the Irish-born war correspondent Cornelius Ryan published his masterly account of the Allied D-Day invasion of Normandy. At the time, Ryan's book was a blockbuster sensation. For nearly a decade he had assembled thousands of recollections of the events of June 6, 1944, by participants from all elements of the invasion: American, British, French and German civilians. Ryan spoke personally or corresponded with everyone-from privates to generals; infantrymen, sailors, airmen, submariners, medics, drivers, paratroopers, glider crews and passengers. He puts us inside the headquarters of the German Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, who was in charge of repelling an invasion, as well as Dwight Eisenhower's tense war room as the general grappled with whether to launch the invasion in the face of stormy weather.

title: Everyone's Attacking Joe Biden
summary: As the campaign begins in earnest, the front-runner becomes the target.. The political phony war has ended and the real shooting has begun. Democratic presidential candidates are fighting on two fronts.

title: The Fed Can't Bail Trump Out
summary: 'Monetary stimulation' didn't help Obama and won't now counter reckless spending and trade wars.. President Trump's April tweet that stocks and economic growth would be higher "if the Fed had done its job properly," is worth re-examining in light of market developments after Mr. Trump won his tussle with Fed Chairman Jerome Powell. Mr. Powell backed off his brief attempt at "quantitative tightening" under presidential and market pressure. Now that the Fed has "done its job properly," where are the salutary results?

title: The Tank That Sank on D-Day
summary: And how my research helped settle an Army-Navy feud 40 years later.. When the Allies landed at Normandy, France, 75 years ago June 6, the U.S. Army introduced a supersecret weapon, the swimming tank, or Duplex Drive. An inflatable canvas skirt was supposed to enable the DD tank to float so the turret rose above the surface. Gen. Dwight Eisenhower had ridden on one and fallen in love at first sight. He raved about how the tanks would emerge from the sea, shocking the Germans and providing armored support for the troops that had gone ashore.

title: Will the EU Kill Video Streaming?
summary: A copyright 'directive' could make it impossible for YouTube, much less an upstart, to do business.. The European Union's Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market takes effect June 7. It is intended to update European policies regarding online intellectual property and shelter fledgling European technology companies against competition from Apple , Google and other foreign tech giants. The irony is that the new directive may end up hampering web-based initiatives everywhere-particularly the very companies it is meant to protect.

title: How to Persuade Parents to Vaccinate Their Kids
summary: The keys are empathy and humility.. The current outbreaks of measles are largely a result of parents being afraid to vaccinate their children-a fear that increased dramatically after a 1998 study in the Lancet falsely linked the vaccine with autism. It took 12 years for the journal to retract the study, which was based on only 12 children. The lead author lost his medical license, but the damage had been done.

title: Prosecutors Are Looking at USC Football Great Pat Haden in College-Admissions Scandal
summary: Investigators focus on possible ties between Haden, also a former USC athletic director, and scheme mastermind William "Rick" Singer. BOSTON-Federal investigators are examining whether former University of Southern California athletic director and NFL quarterback Pat Haden played a role in the national college-admissions cheating scheme, according to a person familiar with the investigation.

summary: 'Beige book' shows modest growth in U.S. economic activity during the spring. The U.S. dollar rose as a Federal Reserve report released Wednesday showed that economic activity ticked up this spring.

summary: Silicon Valley has inspired the Pentagon to modernize its technology and make better use of data. Now the Pentagon is taking a page from tech companies, pushing its software developers to release code faster and with a sharper focus on users-in this case, members of the armed forces.

summary: Declining oil prices also weigh on copper; gold for June delivery up slightly. Copper prices fell Wednesday, pressured by fears over global growth and a steep drop in crude.

summary: The troupe presents works by Alexei Ratmansky and Twyla Tharp, as well as the American premiere of Cathy Marston's lengthy 'Jane Eyre.'.

summary: Beijing is dealing with a quiet manufacturing exodus.. Investors are sending a note of optimism that President Donald Trump and Chinese dictator Xi Jinping may soon resolve their trade dispute. Meanwhile, a manufacturing exodus could be adding increasing pressure on Beijing to cut a deal.

title: GameStop Reboot Faces Long Odds
summary: Shelving the retailer's dividend is a high-risk move to fund more 'transformation' efforts. Even $157 million a year only goes so far in the videogame business. For GameStop , it may not go far enough.

title: Investors Are Too High on the Cloud
summary: Valuations have soared, as cloud software companies see little threat from China or domestic politics. A tech sector not exposed to tariffs, trade wars or domestic political scrutiny sounds almost too good to be true. At current valuations, it just might be.

title: You Need a Pilot When the Computers Fail
summary: Boeing will fix the automation issues with the 737 MAX soon enough, but there will always be times when human pilots will be called on when computers and automation systems have failed them.. Regarding Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.'s "Boeing vs. Pilots?" (Business World, June 1): Without question, the failure of the pilots to deal with a malfunction was a major factor in both 737 MAX accidents. But in the accident chain, and it is almost always a chain of events that cause an airliner to crash, the root cause of both crashes was the failure of the automated flight-control system. As good as automation gets, it will never be flawless and there will be times when a properly trained and competent flight crew will be all that prevents disaster.

title: Protect U.S. Shellfish Without a Trade War
summary: Our response to the risk of importing infected shellfish needs to be legal, effective and guided by the best available science. The knee-jerk response of banning shellfish trade with the EU fails in all three of these criteria.. Keep Europe's Sick Shellfish Out of America

title: Puerto Rico Grid Contractor Caught Up in Federal Probes
summary: A Mammoth Energy Services Inc. subsidiary is caught up in federal probes into disaster spending. An electric utility contractor that turned Puerto Rico's lights back on after Hurricane Maria now is ensnared in contract-steering probes as federal authorities scrutinize billions of dollars in public reconstruction spending across the U.S. territory.

title: Banning Plastic Straws Saves Marine Life
summary: Consider the value of a highly visible corporate leader in disposable-container beverage sales teaching its customers about the issue and perhaps inspiring new economic activity to meet the demand for alternatives.. Regarding Allysia Finley's "Would You Like Guilt with Your Latte?" (op-ed, May 28): I doubt Starbucks ' intention in eliminating plastic straws is to make Ms. Finley feel guilty. More likely the company was inspired by reports of straws hurting marine life, or whales washing up dead because their bellies are filled with plastic. Ms. Finley is correct that these goals can be difficult to meet or may cause unintended consequences. But she fails to recognize the value of a highly visible corporate leader in disposable-container beverage sales teaching its customers about the issue and perhaps inspiring new economic activity to meet the demand for alternatives.

title: Don't Bury Nuclear Waste, Recycle It as the French Do
summary: We should learn from the French who have been recycling nuclear waste at their Cap de la Hague facility near the English Channel since 1976.. Regarding Sen. John Barrasso's "Get Serious About Burying Nuclear Waste" (op-ed, May 29): Don't bury nuclear waste, recycle it, senator. We should learn from the French who have been recycling nuclear waste at their Cap de la Hague facility near the English Channel since 1976. Only a small percentage of nuclear fuel is spent when the fuel rods are used at commercial nuclear power plants. Approximately 95% of these spent rods can be recycled into new, usable fuel rods. A very small percentage of nuclear waste remains to be permanently disposed of.

title: Tariff Fights Are a Drag for Maker of Jack Daniel's
summary: Brown-Forman, already hurt by EU's tariffs on U.S. whiskey, could take another hit if Trump follows through on Mexican tequilas. Tariffs keep squeezing the maker of Jack Daniel's.

title: Outdoor Adventure Begins in Bend
summary: The Central Oregon city offers à la carte activities for adrenaline junkies and outdoor enthusiasts. Locals brag that Bend is the kind of place where you can ski in the morning and golf in the afternoon. But ski-to-tee living is only the beginning. The 94,520-person town located between the Cascade Mountains and Central Oregon's high desert plateaus is the ultimate year-round outdoor base camp for health and adrenaline activities. There are peaks for hiking, biking and rock climbing. Rivers and alpine lakes are for canoeing, kayaking, stand-up paddleboarding, white-water rafting and fly fishing. Horseback riding is huge. Camping is big. And when your adventure is done, head to Bend's Old Mill District along the Deschutes River for shopping and dinner, or grab a pint handcrafted by one of two-dozen or so local breweries in the area like Deschutes Brewery or Bend Brewing Company.

summary: Slicked in a savory caramel sauce, pork belly cooks in minutes on the grill. Then simply wrap it in lettuce leaves along with a tangy carrot-papaya slaw and fresh, flavorful garnishes. title: The Explosive Evolution of Consciousness
summary: About five hundred million years ago, animals suddenly developed eyes and limbs-and possibly an inner life.. Where does consciousness come from? When and how did it evolve? The one person I'm sure is conscious is myself, of course, and I'm willing to believe that my fellow human beings, and familiar animals like cats and dogs, are conscious too. But what about bumblebees and worms? Or clams, oak trees and rocks?

title: Elizabeth Warren Campaign Allows Staff to Unionize
summary: Democratic candidate follows Sen. Bernie Sanders, former HUD Secretary Julián Castro and Rep. Eric Swalwell. WASHINGTON-Sen. Elizabeth Warren's presidential campaign has agreed to let workers unionize, according to the business manager of the union branch that will represent them.

title: Fed's Brainard Says Lower Rates Possible Amid Trade Risks
summary: Fed governor says she will watch data carefully to determine central bank's next step. Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard signaled an openness to lowering interest rates but she didn't indicate such action was imminent.

title: Estée Lauder Executive Chairman Lists Manhattan Home for $45 Million
summary: William P. Lauder is selling his longtime home at 778 Park Avenue, a well-known co-op building. William P. Lauder, executive chairman of beauty giant Estée Lauder and the grandson of founders Estée Lauder and Joseph Lauder, is putting his Manhattan home on the market for $45 million.

title: The New Must-Have Workout Equipment: Socks
summary: The humble sock, now cast as fashionable performance wear, has become the latest status symbol for exercise-class enthusiasts. The new stars of your exercise class: Socks.

title: Fed's Clarida Says Findings of Policy Review Will Be Shared Next Year
summary: Framework used to set and communicate rate decisions will likely be completed in the first half of 2020. CHICAGO-Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Richard Clarida said the central bank's ongoing review of the framework it uses to set and communicate its rate policy decisions will probably be completed in the first half of 2020.

title: Consumer Stocks Take an Early Victory Lap
summary: Shares in Nestlé, P&G and Unilever are trading near record highs even though they continue to lose share to smaller competitors. Investors have decided that the worst is over for the world's top consumer companies, but the bout of optimism is probably premature.

title: Trump Expresses Concern About Gun Silencers in Wake of Virginia Shooting
summary: In interview on British television, President Trump says he would consider a ban but doesn't 'love the idea'. PORTSMOUTH, England-President Trump said he doesn't like gun silencers and was open to considering a ban on the devices after one was used in a mass shooting last week in Virginia.

title: 'I Didn't Want Any Medals': Last D-Day Veterans Make Poignant Return
summary: Survivors of historic invasion go back 75 years later to reflect, reunite and pay respects. COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France-Pvt. Jack Port thought he was fighting the war to end all wars when he stormed Utah Beach on June 6, 1944. Seventy-five years later he sees a world again in conflict.

title: Stocks to Watch: Salesforce, GameStop, Campbell Soup and More
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively on Wednesday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Nonfarm Private Sector Added Just 27,000 Jobs in May, Missing Forecasts
summary: The number was the smallest amount since the economic expansion started. The nonfarm private sector in the U.S. added 27,000 jobs for the month of May, the latest ADP National Employment Report showed, a number that was significantly lower than what economists were expecting.

title: They Regret Their Defense on Stephen Curry. Will the Raptors?
summary: The last time he faced a strategy as extreme as Toronto's box-and-one was in a college game. It didn't work then. But it might in the NBA Finals.. Brian Rudolph still remembers the raspy voice instructing him to do something that sounded so extreme, so preposterous, so insanely radical that he was almost positive he would never see it again.

title: PwC Moves to Overhaul U.K. Audit Business
summary: The Big Four accounting firms have come under pressure from regulators. Professional-services firm PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP on Wednesday announced various measures aimed at overhauling its U.K. audit business, amid growing regulatory concerns about the quality of the country's audit sector.

title: ETF 'Heartbeats' Show Influence of Indexes
summary: Rebalancing can trigger massive money shifts as portfolio managers realign their holdings with updated indexes. A popular BlackRock Inc. exchange-traded fund that tracks companies with healthy balance sheets shed $1.5 billion on a single day last week, the largest outflow in its six-year history.

title: Jaguar Land Rover's Turnaround Ends in China
summary: British car maker's struggles in the world's largest auto market led to multibillion-dollar loss. Jaguar Land Rover was one of the fastest-growing car makers in the U.S. last year, marking a storybook turnaround for the maker of iconic sports cars and off-road vehicles.

title: Permira Nearing Close of $1.7 Billion Growth Fund
summary: Firm typically known for its buyout and credit strategies now trying its hand at growth-stage investing. Permira is approaching the final close of its maiden growth opportunities fund at around $1.7 billion, according to a person familiar with the situation.

title: As Tariffs Bite, Get Ready for a 1970s-Style Supply Shock
summary: Arab oil embargo in early 1970s holds lessons on impact of possible trade war. Market turmoil over mounting U.S. tariffs on China and the threat of the same on Mexico in large part stems from a fear of the unknown: No one knows what a major trade war would do, as the U.S. hasn't been in one since the 1930s.

title: Bristol R&D Chief to Leave After Celgene Acquisition
summary: Bristol-Myers Squibb lays out new management team, says R&D Chief Thomas Lynch Jr.'s job will be split. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. 's research-and-development chief will leave the company later this year after the drugmaker completes its $74 billion acquisition of rival Celgene Corp. and will hand over his responsibilities to a pair of scientists from outside the company.

title: Will China's Tech Titans Be Heavyweights or Overweights?
summary: China's need for new technology champions is at the heart of the conflict with the U.S., but problems at home could be just as big a threat. China's path to technological supremacy has put companies such as Huawei in the Trump administration's crosshairs, but China has even more burning issues in the long run.

title: The Champ Is Here! Meet Andy Ruiz Jr., the Humble Heavyweight
summary: A conversation with boxing's sudden champion, just days after shocking the world. "I'm really good," Andy Ruiz Jr. said when I asked him how he was doing, sounding about as happy as a human being can sound. "Really, really good."

title: College Row, Fifth Avenue Should Brace for Fewer Chinese Visitors
summary: Fewer Chinese tourists may not deal a serious blow to the U.S. but could still cause damage in education and luxury sectors. China's army of globe-trotting tourists has been a handy economic weapon. This may not work as well against the U.S., but could nonetheless cause some damage to sectors such as education and luxury goods.

title: Deal Prognosis Is Healthy for Small Insurers
summary: Limited options for deals mean smaller health-insurance companies deserve a premium valuation. One blockbuster health-insurance deal that investors were hoping for won't happen. But smaller players still should draw interest from potential suitors.

title: Stocks Lure Buyers With Cheapest Valuations in Months
summary: Threat of tariffs has muddied the outlook for equities. One comfort investors have found in the markets' tumult over the past month: Share prices are looking like relative bargains.

title: Life on the Road Gets Easier as Truckers Adopt Technology
summary: AI-driven tools help make deliveries more efficient, boosting productivity. Volker Condron was recently driving an 18-wheel rig on a highway near Mount Vernon, Texas, when his truck blew a tire-a common hazard that can add several hours to a scheduled delivery, he said.

title: Banks Shrug Off Recent Oil-Price Drop to Predict Gains
summary: Investment banks in May largely stuck to their forecasts that oil prices will rise in 2019's final two quarters. LONDON-Investment banks in May largely stuck to their forecasts that oil prices will rise in 2019's final two quarters, predicting that supply risks will make up for sharp selloffs in recent weeks.

title: Cardinal George Pell Appeals His Child Sex Abuse Conviction
summary: His lawyer says the claims against his client were so implausible that the jury should have had reasonable doubt about his guilt. MELBOURNE, Australia-An Australian court has begun hearing arguments seeking to quash the conviction of Cardinal George Pell for the sexual abuse of two young choir boys inside the cathedral that was the center of his diocese in the late 1990s.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: House Democrats Say White House Has Blocked Ex-Trump Aides From Providing Documents
summary: House panel had subpoenaed Hope Hicks and Annie Donaldson for documents related to Mueller probe. WASHINGTON-The White House directed two former administration officials, Hope Hicks and Annie Donaldson, to rebuff congressional subpoenas for certain documents related to the special counsel's probe, the House Judiciary Committee said Tuesday, in the administration's latest effort to block lawmakers' investigations into possible obstruction of justice by the president.

title: Connecticut's $43 Billion Budget Avoids Raising Income-Tax Rates
summary: Two-year spending plan sidesteps fight over tolls and closes $3.7 billion shortfall. Connecticut lawmakers passed a two-year, $43 billion budget that avoids raising income-tax rates and sidesteps a fight over highway tolls.

title: How Safe Is Your Mobile Phone? Not as Safe as You Think
summary: Three experts talk about where the weaknesses are-and what companies can do about it. Websites and apps often ask for users' phone numbers to enhance their security. Those digits allow two-factor authentication: After a user types in a password, the website sends a text message to verify the login attempt is legitimate-the second factor.

title: Lawmakers Set Their Sights on Facial Recognition
summary: As the technology has become more widespread, critics question whether it threatens privacy-or if it is accurate enough to be reliable. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection agency uses facial-recognition software at airports to identify impostors. Stadiums and arenas use it to enhance security. Law-enforcement agencies deploy it to spot suspects.

title: Image-Recognition Technology May Not Be as Secure as We Think
summary: As social networks expand the use of AI-powered image-recognition filters, experts warn that attackers are finding ways to fool them. Last year, engineers at ZeroFOX, a security startup, noticed something odd about a fake social-media profile they'd found of a well-known public figure. Its profile photo had tiny white dots across the face, like a dusting of digital snow. The company's engineers weren't certain, but it looked like the dots were placed to trick a content filter, the kind used by social networks like Facebook to flag celebrity imitations.

title: Companies Struggle to Protect Their Technology Supply Chains
summary: The dizzying global network of components and suppliers makes it hard for companies to even know who their suppliers are. Three years ago, technicians at an Apple Inc. laboratory discovered a worrisome problem with a server that was used by the company's data-analytics division. The server, built for Apple by a company called Super Micro Computer Inc., was infected with malicious software.

title: The Ins and Outs of Cybersecurity Insurance
summary: Policies are designed to help companies survive major cyberattacks. But knowing exactly what's covered can be tricky.. The idea of cybersecurity insurance seems, on its face, pretty straightforward: Being hacked not only can disrupt business, it also can be extremely costly and hurt a company's reputation. Businesses want to protect themselves against those losses.

title: Hackers May Soon Be Able to Tell What You're Typing-Just By Hearing You Type
summary: Research suggests that sound waves from typing on a phone can be intercepted and decoded. Thanks to the increasing sophistication of smartphone technology, hackers soon may be able to intercept and analyze the sounds of typing-and figure out exactly what people are writing on their devices.

title: Fed Puts Interest Rate Cut in Play
summary: Powell's comments suggest central bank is focusing now on whether and when to lower rates. CHICAGO-Markets rallied Tuesday after Federal Reserve officials said they were closely monitoring the recent escalation in trade tensions and indicated they could respond to any economic deterioration by cutting interest rates.

title: The U.S. Needs an NTSB for Cyberattacks
summary: When there's an air crash, we call in the regulators to investigate. Let's do something similar for the biggest hacks.. It's time to take the worst cyberattacks as seriously as air disasters.

title: How to Keep Thieves From Stealing Your PIN at the ATM
summary: 'Skimmers' put cameras near the machines to capture your information. But there are ways to protect yourself.. Your debit cards are in danger.

title: Senate Republicans Threaten to Block Trump on Mexico Tariffs
summary: Trump defends plan and says lawmakers would be making a mistake if they try to stop him. WASHINGTON-Senate Republicans threatened Tuesday to block the White House's planned tariffs on Mexico, hours after President Trump signaled he was prepared to move ahead with the levies barring a last-minute deal over border security.

title: Stocks Surge as Fed Hints at Possible Rate Cut
summary: Dow climbs 512 points in best day for the blue-chip index in five months. U.S. stocks posted their best day in five months on Tuesday, a mark of resilience for a market rally that has recently faced one of its biggest challenges since the financial crisis.

title: Hong Kong Remembers Tiananmen Square Victims 30 Years On
summary: Organizers estimate 180,000 people attend the annual event, equaling record. HONG KONG-More than 180,000 people attended a vigil in Hong Kong to remember victims of the Tiananmen Square massacre 30 years ago, organizers said, equaling the record turnout for the event as locals also voiced anger over a tightening of their own freedoms.

title: What Chocolate Shortage? Cocoa Steadies as Record Projected
summary: Supply concerns made cocoa the best-performing commodity of 2018. The world appears to have averted a chocolate shortage, upending the rally that made cocoa the best-performing commodity in 2018.

title: Don't Over-Monitor Your Kids, Say Readers
summary: Wall Street Journal readers say boundaries should be observed when keeping tabs on children's online lives. As students step out of the classroom and into summer vacation, many parents are concerned about how best to monitor their child's newfound free time-particularly online.

title: LabCorp Patient Data Affected in Breach of Collection Firm's Systems
summary: Billing-collections vendor is sending notices to about 200,000 consumers whose credit card or bank-account information may have been exposed. Medical-testing giant Laboratory Corp. of America said 7.7 million of its patients may be affected by the same data breach at a collections firm that also did business with Quest Diagnostics Inc.
